pros: Great team to work with
cons: Some extremely toxic and back stabbing people from other departments.

pros: Decent amount of paid holidays, paid sick leave.
cons: No longer a beacon of education in language teaching and teacher training. Sh**** upper management and a school now run by sales and marketing rather than an academic team. Teachers told to give feedback as nothng more than a box-ticking exercise. No one heeds any input from teachers or Senior Academic Staff. More interested in bums on seats, even if those seats are filled with highly disruptive, dysfunctional SEN students who should not be given a place. Even mid-management is willing to sacrifice the 10+ other students' right to a calm, focused learning environment if it means keeping the money paid by the uber-SEN's parents. 'Kids won't really complain about it, will they, ? We only see them once a week,' think management. Disgusting. Furthermore, the organization has been eviscerated from within by poor management decisions and bullshittery involving cookie-cutter approach to centres across the globe. No longer teaching to the local context. Sinking ship that started losing it's identity pre-Covid.

pros: People from all roles and different departments are friendly at BC. Support is provided across all levels which is helpful when you are getting on board.
cons: As a global organisation, you may need to be a little more patient before things can be rolled out.

pros: Great teachers, poor managers, poor head office
cons: Understanding some of the poor business decisions

pros: Benefits for a part time staff not bad. Culture was good
cons: Over the years management quality went down and right now it’s rather messy

pros: Attractive work environment. Chances for training and promotion.
cons: Managers do not listen to feedback from teachers.

pros: good colleagues, benefits, annual leave
cons: low pay and long hours

pros: Great classrooms for teaching for various ages
cons: Red tape, hr is in another country

pros: Great mission. Interesting / qualified colleagues. Lots of room for learning and development
cons: Business outlook not great. Slow moving. Compensation just so so.

review_title: Good career opportunity to learn but organisation could provide better support to staff
pros: Wide exposure and opportunity to learn in a global organization Diverse, vibrant environment Good benefits beyond salary (e.g leave, insurance, etc.)
cons: lack of leadership and foresight in management poor communication disparity between local and expat contracts/opportunities lack of support or onboarding for staff

review_title: Used to be a standout organisation
pros: Medical insurance coverage is top notch
cons: Orgsnisation has been slowly cost cutting before the pandemic. When Covid 19 hit , they suddenly have the perfect excuse to let people go and did not pay any retrenchment package. Management handled layoffs poorly - no care, compassion or respect. While most are getting laid off though, there are one or few select that have been getting salary increments!

pros: Great work insurance cover Supportive management and leadership WFH flexibility
cons: Not much opportunity for career progression

pros: -good healthcare -great vacation time -better than average pay (depends on location)
cons: -HR restructuring and elimination of local HR by country -company restructuring and cost-cutting leaves the BC feeling like a shell of its former self -management always seems overburdened

pros: Independency and able to work creatively
cons: Zero structure in the organization. Outsourced HR and hard to contact

pros:
Decent salary for the industry
Supportive colleagues - especially local staff
Varied work - both academic and non-academic
cons:
Not enough training opportunities
Work/life balance

pros: Friendly colleagues. Reputation based on good old days.
cons: Disorganised management, high turnover rate

pros: Reputable language school in Singapore
cons: Too many to list - undeserved reputation

pros: No prospects and no increment
cons: Good work timing and flexibility

pros: There are many professional colleagues
cons: You may not have a choice of location or age groups of learners you teach.

pros: People are very comfortable thus not putting much effort in work
cons: Some toxic people and toxic environment, bad politics

review_title: It was a great place to teach
pros: The students were wonderful, the job was great once you were in class.
cons: The council is going through some major changes, which can be stressful.

pros: work life imbalance is great
cons: everything that can stem from a combination of incompetence and charity money

pros:
professional colleagues
nice students
good insurance and long paid holidays
cons: The salary could be higher since living in Singapore is very expensive.

review_title: Overall, a good company to work for
pros:
1)	Easy paced environment 
2)	Flexibility when working and Good Work life balance (for non-customer facing roles)
3)	Lesser working hours a week that the average work week
4)	High emphasis on Equal Opportunity, Diversity and Inclusive with non-discriminatory hiring. 
5)	Fair promotion policy based on open recruitment for each role
cons:
1) Salary not competitive and way below market average
2) Company currently going through a transition

review_title: Lots of benefits, but hard to rise up ranks
pros: Lots of benefits. Pro-family environment
cons: Career Path can be uncertain

pros:
Flexible working hours, works well for full-time students 
Managers are understanding of needing to take into consideration changes in school schedule
cons: Scheduling can be a bit messy

pros: Global reputation, past work and initiatives
cons: Little development or innovation to keep up with the market

pros:
- Resources for teaching
- Global policy clearly stated
- Quality of teaching staff
cons:
- Schedule
- Lack of direction and accountability from upper management

pros: They provided short working hours
cons: multiple classes of the same level

pros: Some committed and competent colleagues
cons:
Lack of quality in systems and products - management opt for what's easiest in the moment rather than focus on quality
Painfully slow to understand the competitive realities of teaching English in the digital age

pros: Decent benefits with good colleagues
cons: Leadership micromanages but doesn’t lead or make clear decisions. Communication can be abusive and patronizing.

pros: Respectful of individual working hours
cons: Clearly, management is not certain of the direction to grow the company and adopts a wait-and-see attitude. Takes a long time to make decisions, and when made, they are rushed, imbalanced decisions. It is alarming that a company can run without a local HR and Finance presence.

pros: There are other opportunities out there
cons: There is nothing to add on...

pros: Great colleagues, interesting students, great training opportunities
cons: A lot of bureaucracy and red tape

pros: Supportive colleagues, flexible working environment
cons: Lack of communication from senior leadership

review_title: Missing talent pipeline, hi-po system, career progression
pros:
21 days of annual leave
37.5 working hours per week
a great place to retire
cons:
poor salary
in the local context there is no career progression, there is no talent pipeline, there is no training needs analysis, there is no identification of high potentials, and talent is lost to competitors. vacancies are hired externally while internal staff gets no support to grow/develop/upgrade. zero opportunity to take on senior roles internally because such roles are usually give to external hires or UK expats.
annual batch recruitment exercise is conducted for senior roles across the world and such roles are perceived to be generally reserved for UK expats only because it is basically a merry-go-round between the selected few. such opportunities or batch type exercise is not provided to junior level management or even executives and middle management.
company is quickly becoming top heavy and bottom lean, and inverted triangle. expanding regional teams while cutting manpower in operational and business support units, teaching centres making a huge loss.
poor hr practices.
processes and procedures move at a glacial pace.

review_title: Great care of  staff welfare, business side is lacking
pros: They genuinely care for staff welfare. Great work/life balance with decent pay for the industry in Singapore.  The values, vision and mission also mean that the work often comes with a sense of higher purpose.
cons: The company lacks real direction and you are often asked to do work for products that are obvious duds. Promotion is also hard as senior posts tend to be filled by expats or external hires. e.g Country Director and Head of  Teaching Centre is always an expat.

review_title: Inclusive environment, but poor internal progression
pros: Friendly, international work environment with an emphasis on open communication and inclusiveness, has great staff benefits and supports employees in both professional and personal development. Internal courses open to staff for free/at discounted rates. Regional teams foster regular sharing of best practices and help synergise efforts (some teams more effective than others). Environmentally-conscious.
cons: Pays well below market for non-teaching roles (especially if you are non-revenue generating), particularly in support departments. Poor prospects for internal progression (no internal promotions), though lateral transfers are possible. Not attractive for young executives looking for quick career growth. If you're not moving up after 2-3 years, move out, or you may find yourself stuck.

pros: The organisation does interesting work and some of the staff are friendly and have interesting backgrounds. Work life balance is generally very good for a company in Singapore.
cons: Outdated office and facilities, very uncompetitive performance bonus, culture of hiring senior management from overseas (the UK) rather than growing talent from within. Unfriendly academic staff

pros:
1. International colleagues - interesting, friendly, helpful people. Some branches and teams seem to have a better vibe than others. 

2. Good learning environment. 

3. Some job functions allow you good work-life balance. Working overtime is not part of the culture.
cons:
1. Management shows little care for people. Concerns and suggestions are swept aside.

2. Very volatile environment in past year or two, even before Covid. 

3. Renumeration package and terms for some locals is poor; might even flout labour laws.

review_title: interesting, challenging, teaching in various places under varying conditions.
pros: I would say that for those who like to travel, are tough in character and resilience, this is a good place to be.
cons: The long, unsociable hours and poor working conditions can make the work demoralising and uncomfortable for  responsible, sensitive or inflexible perfectionists.

review_title: Redundancy of older, long serving teachers
pros: High profile reputation. Good training & professional development opportunities. Reasonable pay.
cons: Parachute managers who are overly concerned with furthering their personal ambitions. Lack of transparency & poor communication around change management & handling of poor performance. The place is full of managers but bereft of true leaders.

pros: There are lots of opportunities to get involved in projects and work across departments.
cons: There has been a pay freeze since 2008. Both pay and conditions are gradually being eroded in what is the most expensive city/country to live in the world.

review_title: Poor working culture and unprofessional environment.
pros: Variety of work and chance to teach a range of levels.
cons: Little progression or staff training or development  within the organisation. Products are very poorly written and put together - basically surviving on name alone. Product leads take very little responsibility for the low quality and do not respond well to feedback.

review_title: Good for benefits; slow progression path
pros: Good compensation package, minimum 21 days AL with reasonable performance bonus. The company also supports staff in upgrading skills with many courses (professional & non-professional) being put in place by the company / outside of the company.
cons: Hardly any career progression path

review_title: Business Development Manager / Country Exams Manager
pros: Leadership opportunities and autonomy to an extent
cons: Historically disorganised system within local department, which newcomer will be expected to clean up - think twice before joining the position

pros: 21 days of leave, L&D, good benefits, supportive colleagues (Depends on which dept)
cons: No progression, unclear direction from mgmt

pros: Nice colleagues; remote operations due to hot desking; 21 days of leave
cons: 1) lack of clear business strategies from top management (2)  bureaucratic in decision-making (3) HODs lack of industry experience

pros: Excellent work life balance and very collaborative management
cons: Nothing that I can think of though. The pace is slow anyway.

pros: Friendly colleagues who are always helpful and great culture.
cons: The shifts are not regular.

pros: 1.5 Bonus and 21 days leave
cons: If you fancy endless paperwork, follow ups and duplicate task

pros: Good working environment, flexible working hours.
cons: Limited office space for employees.
